item.description:
The full address:

List Arts Building, room 120, Brown University 64 College Street Providence, RI
The lecture starts at 5:30, however, given how crowded the beer and wine lecture was last month, I'm suggesting getting there a bit early.  I'll be there at 5. From the Haffenreffer Museum Facebook Event: (please RSVP their as well so the staff knows what to expect). Mexican food has joined Chinese and Italian as one of the three most popular ethnic varieties in the United States - though, of course, the tacos and burritos we eat now are no more representative of the cuisines of Mexico than chop suey and pizza are of Chinese and Italian. Moreover, the American version of Mexican food has spread around the world, to the chagrin of Mexicans who find Tex-Mex wherever they travel. In this lecture historian Jeffrey Pilcher (University of Minnesota) will follow the history of Mexican American food from the "chili queens" of San Antonio and the taco shops of southern California to their contemporary global versions.
item.how_to_find_us: I'll be sure to have something identifiable (like a sign)
item.why: A history/anthropology lecture about food. In this case, Mexican food.
item.name: Planet Taco: The Globalization of Mexican Cuisine
